events.originalText: The Shard (pictured) in London was inaugurated as the tallest building in Europe, with a height of 310 m (1,020 ft), but was surpassed by Moscow's Mercury City Tower four months later.
events.subtitle: The Shard
events.headline: The Shard in London becomes tallest building in Europe

events.originalText: The largest hoard of Anglo-Saxon gold ever discovered, consisting of more than 1,500 items, was found near the village of Hammerwich, near Lichfield, in Staffordshire.
events.subtitle: Anglo-Saxons
events.headline: Largest hoard of Anglo-Saxon gold found near Hammerwich

events.originalText: A series of violent riots broke out in Ürümqi, the capital city of Xinjiang in China.
events.subtitle: July 2009 Ürümqi riots
events.headline: Violent riots erupt in Ürümqi, China

events.originalText: The United Nations Security Council held an emergency meeting hours after North Korea reportedly tested at least seven ballistic missiles.
events.subtitle: United Nations Security Council
events.headline: UN Security Council emergency meeting after North Korea missile tests

events.originalText: Indonesia held its first direct presidential elections, which resulted in the election of Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono as President of Indonesia after the second round on September 20.
events.subtitle: 2004 Indonesian presidential election
events.headline: Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono elected President of Indonesia

events.originalText: United States National Security Council member Oliver North was given a suspended sentence, probation, and community service for his part in the Iran–Contra affair.
events.subtitle: United States National Security Council
events.headline: Oliver North sentenced for Iran-Contra affair involvement

events.originalText: Juvénal Habyarimana (pictured) orchestrated a bloodless coup d'état of the Rwandan government and began a totalitarian dictatorship.
events.subtitle: Juvénal Habyarimana
events.headline: Juvénal Habyarimana stages coup in Rwanda

events.originalText: The Rolling Stones performed at a free festival in Hyde Park, London, in front of at least a quarter of a million fans, two days after the death of founder Brian Jones.
events.subtitle: The Rolling Stones
events.headline: The Rolling Stones perform at free festival in Hyde Park

events.originalText: Elvis Presley recorded his first single, "That's All Right", at Sun Records in Memphis, Tennessee.
events.subtitle: Elvis Presley
events.headline: Elvis Presley records first single at Sun Records

events.originalText: Korean War: In the first encounter between North Korean and American forces, an unprepared and undisciplined U.S. Army task force was routed at the Battle of Osan.
events.subtitle: Korean War
events.headline: Korean War: U.S. Army task force routed at Battle of Osan

events.originalText: Named after Bikini Atoll, the site of the nuclear-weapons test Operation Crossroads in the Marshall Islands, the modern bikini was introduced at a fashion show in Paris.
events.subtitle: Bikini Atoll
events.headline: Modern bikini introduced at fashion show in Paris

events.originalText: Second World War: Canadian troops defeated the last German counterattacks against Carpiquet, Normandy, France.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Canadian troops defeat German counterattacks in Normandy

events.originalText: The Hormel Foods Corporation introduced Spam, the canned precooked meat product that would eventually enter into pop culture, folklore, and urban legend.
events.subtitle: Hormel Foods
events.headline: Hormel Foods introduces Spam canned meat product

events.originalText: Brazilian Army rebels took over Fort Copacabana and launched a rebellion in Rio de Janeiro against the president of Brazil.
events.subtitle: Tenentism
events.headline: Brazilian Army rebels take over Fort Copacabana in Rio de Janeiro

events.originalText: Frederick Douglass gave his speech known as "What to the Slave Is the Fourth of July?", arguing that positive statements about liberty, citizenship, and freedom, were an offense to the enslaved population of the United States because of their lack of those things.
events.subtitle: Frederick Douglass
events.headline: Frederick Douglass delivers speech on Fourth of July

events.originalText: Thomas Cook, the founder of the British travel company Thomas Cook & Son, organised his first excursion, escorting about 500 people from Leicester to Loughborough.
events.subtitle: Thomas Cook
events.headline: Thomas Cook organises first excursion from Leicester to Loughborough
